title: Problem Overview
content: Erdős Problem #144: Does the density of integers with close divisors (d₁ < d₂ < 2d₁) equal 1? SOLVED by Maier-Tenenbaum (1984). Prize: $250 (reportedly $650 paid). The threshold β* = log 3 - 1 separates density 1 from density 0 in the refined version.
mathContext: From Erdős [Er79]. Related to Erdős-Hall [ErHa79]. Connects to probabilistic number theory and divisor distribution.

title: Natural Density and Close Divisors
content: naturalDensity(A, d): density d(A) = lim |A ∩ {1,...,n}|/n. hasCloseDivisors(n): ∃ d₁ d₂ with d₁|n, d₂|n, d₁ < d₂ < 2d₁. hasCloseDivisorsC(c, n): generalized with d₂ < c·d₁. closeDivisorsSet and closeDivisorsSetC: the corresponding sets.
mathContext: naturalDensity defined via ε-N formulation. Close divisors captures 'propinquity' — two divisors within a factor of 2.

title: Maier-Tenenbaum Theorem
content: erdos_144_conjecture: naturalDensity closeDivisorsSet 1. maier_tenenbaum_theorem (axiom): erdos_144_conjecture holds. maier_tenenbaum_strong (axiom): for all c > 1, density of c-close divisors = 1.
mathContext: Both the basic version (c = 2) and strong version (arbitrary c > 1) are axiomatized from Maier-Tenenbaum [MaTe84].

title: Critical Exponent and Refined Close Divisors
content: criticalExponent: β* = log 3 - 1 ≈ 0.0986. hasRefinedCloseDivisors(β, n): ∃ d₁, d₂ with d₂ < d₁·(1 + (log n)^{-β}). refinedCloseDivisorsSet(β): the set of integers with (β)-close divisors.
mathContext: β* = Real.log 3 - 1 is the critical threshold. The refined version uses (log n)^{-β} decay in divisor ratio.

title: Phase Transition
content: erdos_hall_theorem (axiom): β > β* → density = 0. maier_tenenbaum_refined (axiom): β < β* → density = 1. phase_transition (proved): combines both into a sharp threshold result.
mathContext: phase_transition := ⟨erdos_hall_theorem, maier_tenenbaum_refined⟩. Density jumps from 0 to 1 at β* = log 3 - 1.

title: Examples
content: prime_powers_fail (axiom): p^k has no close divisors (consecutive divisors differ by factor p ≥ 2). hasCloseDivisors 6 (proved): d₁=2, d₂=3 works. hasCloseDivisors 12 (proved): d₁=3, d₂=4 works.
mathContext: Examples proved by norm_num. Prime power failure explains the density-0 exceptional set.

title: Historical Context
content: Erdős claimed proof in 1964 [Er64h] but retracted in 1979 [ErHa79]. Erdős-Hall proved density 0 for β > β* in 1979. Maier-Tenenbaum completed the picture in 1984, vindicating the original conjecture.
mathContext: Placeholder axioms recording the historical sequence: retracted claim → partial result → full resolution.

title: Proof Techniques
content: Key methods: divisor distribution (clustering around √n), Erdős-Kac theorem (ω(n) ~ N(log log n, log log n)), probabilistic arguments, and moment calculations for bounding exceptional sets.
mathContext: Placeholder axioms. The actual proof uses deep results from multiplicative number theory.

title: Related Problems and Prize
content: Related to Erdős Problem #449 (divisor ratios), Problem #884 (divisor gaps), and Guy's Problem E3. Prize: $250 offered, reportedly $650 paid to Tenenbaum for solving both versions.
mathContext: Placeholder axioms recording connections to related problems and historical prize information.

title: Summary: SOLVED
content: erdos_144_status (proved): erdos_144_conjecture ∧ (∀ c > 1, erdos_144_strong_conjecture c). Proved from maier_tenenbaum_theorem and maier_tenenbaum_strong. Problem SOLVED.
mathContext: erdos_144_status := ⟨maier_tenenbaum_theorem, fun c hc => maier_tenenbaum_strong c⟩.
